  Hey John,

  brief research. Where does one find them for sale and for how much?

  Mark

    -----Original Message-----

    Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


    Mark and Andres;

    The most useful English language reference books in my experience are the
  translations of the Nihon To Koza by Harry Watson.

    John
      ----- Original Message -----
      From: Andres Pedraza
      To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
      Sent: Thursday, August 04, 2005 6:22 AM
      Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] new release dvd


      Mark,

      I have both books. Yumoto's is a magnificent pocket reference,
      although a bit dated. The Connoisseur's is a much more detailed
      reference, covering the same ground as Yumoto's, but with more
      examples of every feature a nihonto can have. Curiously enough, every
      now and then I see it being offered on eBay, sometimes reaching bid
      amounts above 100 dollars. For the life of me, I can't understand
      why. Not that the book isn't worth it, but because it's still
      available off the shelf at Amazon for less than 50 bucks:

  http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/4770020716&link_code=as
  2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

      Now, that being said, the Connoisseur's is probably the best
      reference available in English. It pales in comparison to published
      in Japan nihonto reference books which can make the Connoisseur's
      look like the pocket reference version.

      Lastly, another book I found to be a good read, especially as it
      covers nihonto manufacture, is The Craft of the Japanese Sword, by
      Leon Kapp, also available from Amazon:

  http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=ASIN/087011798X&link_code=as
  2&camp=1789&tag=lairofthenecr-20&creative=9325

      Hope that helps.

      Regards,

      Andres

      At 08:39 AM 8/4/2005, you wrote:
      >Guess you're missing Andres point here.  This is a message board, NOT
  an
      >advertising board. You posted your message once, everyone would have
  seen
      >it, you did your job. You have plenty of other venues to peddle this
  dvd.
      >Unfortunately, THIS place isn't it.
      >THAT was the point Andres was trying to make.
      >
      >Just got John Yumoto's "The Samurai Sword" in the mail yesterday!  Any
      >sugestions out there for a must have "second" reference book? Just
  keeping
      >things basic at this point. Not specializing in any one specific area
  yet.
      >Has anyone read "The Connoisseur's Book of Japoanese Swords"?
      >
      >Mark
